citeinfo.title: Gulf Watch Alaska Nearshore Component: Monitoring Site Locations from Prince William Sound, Katmai National Park and Preserve, and Kenai Fjords National Park

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

citeinfo.othercit: Suggested Citation: Heather A. Coletti, Kimberly A. Kloecker, James L. Bodkin, and Tom A. Dean, 2017, Gulf Watch Alaska Nearshore Component: Monitoring Site Locations from Prince William Sound, Katmai National Park and Preserve, and Kenai Fjords National Park: U.S. Geological Survey data release, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F78S4N3R.

citeinfo.origin: The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council
citeinfo.title: Gulf Watch Alaska

pubinfo.publish: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council (EVOSTC)

citeinfo.othercit: Gulf Watch Alaska is the long-term ecosystem monitoring program of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council for the marine ecosystem affected by the 1989 oil spill.

descript.abstract: These data are part of the Gulf Watch Alaska (GWA) long term monitoring program, nearshore monitoring component. Specifically, these data describe site locations for rocky intertidal, mussel sampling, soft sediment bivalve sampling, and eelgrass bed sampling in the northern Gulf of Alaska within the GWA program. The dataset consists of two comma separated files exported from a Microsoft Excel workbook. The data consists of 1. rocky intertidal, mussel sampling, and soft sediment site location information, and 2. eelgrass bed locations. Sampling will be conducted in Katmai National Park and Preserve (KATM), Kenai Fjords National Park (KEFJ), Prince William Sound (PWS) and to a lesser extent on the Lake Clark National Park and Preserve (LACL). Sites from a related project that provides similar data from Kachemak Bay (KBAY) are included here.
descript.purpose: This data set contains specific location information for the sampling sites of the nearshore component of the Gulf Watch Alaska long term monitoring program. The number and location of sampling units differ among metrics, but in general the design calls for sampling at multiple locations within each area. Sampling locations were selected to provide a random, spatially balanced distribution. The design allows for detection of large temporal or spatial-scale changes. For some metrics the design will also allow for detection of changes that may occur on a more localized scale.
descript.supplinf: These site locations are a component of the nearshore monitoring portion of the Gulf Watch Alaska (GWA) program. The Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council and state and federal agencies are supporting a five-year, $12 million long-term monitoring program in the Gulf of Alaska region affected by the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill. The monitoring program, called GulfWatch, includes 25 principal scientists and seeks to provide data to identify and help understand the impacts of multiple ecosystem factors on the recovery of injured resources. This program is expected to be 20 years in total length, but planned and funded in five-year increments. It builds upon the past 23 years of restoration research and monitoring by the EVOSTC and federal and state agencies. Monitoring efforts will span a range of species and marine conditions, organized in three components, with integrated data management and synthesis of science information provided across the components. The program includes sites in Prince William Sound, lower Cook Inlet and the outer Kenai Peninsula coast. Environmental Drivers component - oceanography, plankton. Nearshore component - intertidal invertebrate and algae, sea otters, seabirds, lingering oil. Pelagic component - whales, seabirds, forage fish.

spdom.descgeog: The Gulf of Alaska: specific blocks from Prince William Sound (east, north, and west), Kenai Fjords National Park, Katmai National Park and Preserve.

idinfo.useconst: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. Any person using the information here should fully understand the data collection procedures before beginning analyses. The burden for determining fitness of use lies entirely with the user. For purposes of publication of dissemination, citations or credit should be given to the authors and USGS. USGS grants to the public a non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use these data for non-commercial educational or scientific research purposes. Please let owner know when data are used and cite primary authors and database when using or publishing these data. This material is based upon work funded by the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council under Project/Program No. 12120114-R. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views or positions of the Trustee Council.
idinfo.datacred: Many people (USGS staff, contractors, and NPS staff) deserve thanks and recognition for the selection of sites and the location information contained in this data set. The following were instrumental in site selection and establishment: James Bodkin, Heather Coletti, Tom Dean, Alan Bennett, Bill Thompson, Meg Hahr, and Claudette Moore.
idinfo.native: The original data are stored as a Microsoft Excel workbook in a Windows operating environment, but have been exported as comma separated text files for dissemination.

attracc.attraccr: Site end points were spatially verified by repeated site visits to confirm or edit their correct position. Physical site locations were initially established and marked with stainless steel marker plates bolted to the rock (for rocky intertidal and mussel sites) or 18-24 inch rebar stakes with garden hose covers pounded into the site (soft sediment sites). GPS coordinates were collected using hand held Garmin GPS Map 76csx units set for NAD83. Waypoints and marker locations were verified and refined in subsequent years by additional observers as they re-located sites for repeat sampling. Uncertainty may exist for site locations as sometimes marker plates and rebar stakes are difficult to find in the intertidal. The program is in the process of building a 'site finder' book for each region for field crews to use when re-visiting sites. In addition to site coordinates it will include photos to aid in finding site markers or starting points for transects.

dataqual.logic: These data have been checked for accuracy by visually inspecting plots using GIS tools as well as finding the site markers each year during field sampling events.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted. A site is here defined as an approximately 50 to 100-meter section of coastline and the water directly adjacent to it. Site coordinates refer to the marker placed at the starting end point of the site. For rocky and mussel sites this is a stainless steel plate bolted to the rock. For soft sediment sites this is a length of rebar with a piece of garden hose pounded into the sediment and a marker plate attached to the rebar. Eelgrass coordinates mark four corner buoys that outline the perimeter of the bed being monitored or a center point of the bed as indicated in the data.

method.methdesc: Discrete sampling sites used to sample intertidal invertebrates and algae on sheltered rocky shorelines were selected using a generalized random tessellation stratified (GRTS) sampling scheme. This design provides a random yet spatially balanced distribution of sites within block. A GRTS design also allows for expansion or contraction of the number of sites to be sampled over time by pre-selecting a large number of sites that are ordered with respect to priority. Thus, sampling sites can be added or deleted without compromising the statistical or spatial integrity of the design. Rocky intertidal sampling sites were selected using a Windows-based GRTS sampling software program. See Protocol narrative for Marine Nearshore Ecosystem Monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756 for details.

citeinfo.origin: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti.
citeinfo.title: Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756.
citeinfo.othercit: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

method.methdesc:
Sampling of intertidal invertebrates on sand/gravel beaches, mussels in mussel beds, and eelgrass are sampled at sites of appropriate habitat type that are closest to the randomly selected rocky intertidal sites. We chose to focus samplings for these metrics around the randomly selected rocky sites rather than an independent set of randomly selected sites because of the logistical constraints (a reduction in travel time between sites) and because of a desire to geographically link sites for sampling of all metrics as closely as possible while still maintaining a random component.
Clam and mussel sites were identified by appropriate habitats (unconsolidated sediments for clam and consolidated rocky for mussels) and the presence of clams and mussels.
Transects used for estimating black oystercatcher density were centered on rocky intertidal sites.
Sea otter foraging observations are made at sites wherever sea otters are seen foraging within a 5 km radius of rocky intertidal sampling sites.
Water quality metrics (contaminants in mussels, temperature, and salinity) are measured at sites identified for sampling of intertidal invertebrates on rocky shores. Temperature and salinity are sampled at the rocky intertidal sites and contaminants will be measured in mussels collected from either rocky intertidal or nearby mussel sites.
In addition to sites selected using the GRTS design, sampling has also been conducted at several sites that were selected based on their proximity to locations of probable future impact from shoreline development, sites with historical data of interest, or sites of special interest to local citizens.

citeinfo.origin: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti.

spdoinfo.indspref: Sites in the Gulf of Alaska in Prince William Sound, the Katmai coast, the Kenai Fjords coast, and around Kachemak Bay.

enttyp.enttypd: This is spreadsheet data exported as a comma delimited file. Each record (row) represents one monitoring site.

attr.attrdef: Largest Spatial Designation for these analyses. The Gulf Watch Alaska Nearshore Monitoring component has three regions where monitoring sites are located: AKP = Alaska Peninsula, KEP = Kenai Peninsula, PWS = Prince William Sound. Each region has 3 blocks, of which one has been chosen for intensive sampling. The remaining blocks in a region will be sampled extensively, if time, finding, and motivation allow.
attr.attrdefs: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

attr.attrdef: Unit within the region, Two-digit number for the sampling block. This should be a text field but is often recognized as numeric and the leading zero is eliminated from the value, e.g. block 05 becomes block 5. They are the same block.
attr.attrdefs: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

attr.attrdef: Sites are the smallest spatial scale, designating more specific location of mussel sampling sites. These data are designed to be analyzed at the Region level, but site level analyses will also be used. Site codes are a combination of region, block, and site number as well as the type of sampling. Sites RI_01-RI_05, SI_01-SI_05, and MI_01 - MI_05 are used in each intensively sampled block within each region, while Sites RE_01-RE_05, SE_01-SE_05, and ME_01-ME_05 are used in extensively sampled blocks within PWS. R = Rocky Intertidal sampling, S = soft sediment sampling, and M = mussel sampling, I = Intensive block, E = Extensive block. RS and SS sites were rocky selected and soft selected rather than being randomly chosen. Sites also have names (e.g. Kukak) that are easier to use in the field while this formal code incorporates region and block information for more detailed descriptor. Site_ID has also been called Sitecode in some Gulf Watch data sets.
attr.attrdefs: producer defined and Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

attr.attrdef: Sites are the smallest spatial scale, designating more specific location of sampling sites. Site names can refer to mussel, rocky intertidal, soft sediment, or eelgrass sampling. These data are designed to be analyzed at the Region level, but site level analyses will also be used. Site_Name is a common name for sampling site that is easier and more intuitive to use in the field than site numbers or codes.

edom.edomvd: intertidal mussel sampling site
rocky intertidal sampling site
soft or unconsolidated sediment sampling site

attr.attrdef: Generalized Random Tessellation Stratified sampling scheme sequential number. GRTS provides a random yet spatially balanced distribution of sites within each block. The first 5 sites within a block to be randomly chosen were used. In some cases sites were unusable so the next available sequential GRTS number was chosen. For sites that were selected rather than being randomly chosen, this field is not applicable (NA).
date site was first sampled or set up

enttyp.enttypd: This is spreadsheet data exported as a comma delimited file. Each record (row) represents one eelgrass monitoring site corner.

attr.attrdef: Largest Spatial Designation for these analyses. The Gulf Watch Alaska Nearshore Monitoring component has three regions where monitoring sites are located: AKP = Alaska Peninsula, KEP = Kenai Peninsula, PWS = Prince William Sound. Each region has 3 blocks, of which one has been chosen for intensive sampling. The remaining blocks in a region will be sampled extensively, if time, finding, and motivation allow.
attr.attrdefs: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

attr.attrdef: Unit within the region, Two-digit number for the sampling block. This should be a text field but is often recognized as numeric and the leading zero is eliminated from the value, e.g. block 05 becomes block 5. They are the same block.
attr.attrdefs: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

edom.edomvd: One of 3 blocks on the Kenai Peninsula. This block encompasses Kachemak Bay (KBAY).
One of 3 blocks on the Kenai Peninsula. This block encompasses Kenai Fjords National Park and Preserve (KEFJ).
One of 3 blocks in Prince William Sound. This block is comprised of the northern Sound (NPWS).
One of 3 blocks in Prince William Sound. This block is comprised of the western Sound (WPWS).
One of 3 blocks in Prince William Sound. This block is comprised of the eastern Sound (EPWS).
One of 3 blocks on the Alaska Peninsula. This block encompasses Katmai National Park and Preserve (KATM).
One of 3 blocks on the Alaska Peninsula. This block encompasses Lake Clark National Park and Preserve (LACL).

attr.attrdef: Unit within the region, Four-character name for the sampling block. Often used because it is more intuitive than the block number.
attr.attrdefs: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

edom.edomvd: One of 3 blocks on the Alaska Peninsula. This block encompasses Katmai National Park and Preserve. Block_Number is 10.
One of 3 blocks on the Kenai Peninsula. This block encompasses Kenai Fjords National Park and Preserve. Block_Number is 05.
One of 3 blocks on the Kenai Peninsula. This block encompasses Kachemak Bay. Block_Number is 04.
One of 3 blocks in Prince William Sound. This block is comprised of the western Sound. Block_Number is 08.
One of 3 blocks in Prince William Sound. This block is comprised of the eastern Sound. Block_Number is 09.
One of 3 blocks in Prince William Sound. This block is comprised of the northern Sound. Block_Number is 07.

attr.attrdef: Sites are the smallest spatial scale, designating more specific location of mussel sampling sites. These data are designed to be analyzed at the Region level, but site level analyses will also be used. Site codes are a combination of region, block, and site number as well as the type of sampling. Sites RI_01-RI_05, SI_01-SI_05, and MI_01 - MI_05 are used in each intensively sampled block within each region, while Sites RE_01-RE_05, SE_01-SE_05, and ME_01-ME_05 are used in extensively sampled blocks within PWS. R = Rocky Intertidal sampling, S = soft sediment sampling, and M = mussel sampling, I = Intensive block, E = Extensive block. RS and SS sites were rocky selected and soft selected rather than being randomly chosen. Sites also have names (e.g. Kukak) that are easier to use in the field while this formal code incorporates region and block information for more detailed descriptor. Site_ID has also been called Sitecode in some Gulf Watch data sets.
attr.attrdefs: producer defined and Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

attr.attrdef: Sites are the smallest spatial scale, designating more specific location of sampling sites. Site names can refer to mussel, rocky intertidal, soft sediment, or eelgrass sampling. These data are designed to be analyzed at the Region level, but site level analyses will also be used. Site_Name is a common name for sampling site that is easier and more intuitive to use in the field than site numbers or codes.
attr.attrdefs: producer defined and Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

attr.attrdef: latitude of the center of the eelgrass bed or of one of the four corners of the eelgrass bed site.
longitude of the center of the eelgrass bed or of one of the four corners of the eelgrass bed site.

attr.attrdefs: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

edom.edomvd: eelgrass bed sampling site

overview.eaover: The information contained in these datasets includes region, block, and site information, type of site and latitude and longitude for sites.
overview.eadetcit: Dean, T. A., J. L. Bodkin, H. A. Coletti. 2014. Protocol narrative for marine nearshore ecosystem monitoring in the Gulf of Alaska: Version 1.1. Natural Resource Report NPS/SWAN/NRR - 2014/756. National Park Service, Fort Collins, Colorado.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This material is based upon work funded by the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council under Project/Program No. 12120114-R. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views or positions of the Trustee Council.

digtinfo.formcont: Zip file containing data files in CSV file format and FGDC metadata in XML and HTML formats.
digtinfo.filedec: Use WinZip, pkUnzip, or other open source or commercially available unzip tool.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Biological Data Profile of the Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
